Q: Taking advantage of memory contiguousness in HLSL A:

As you are using 256 threads per thread group like 256 right?
if yes try to use the unity profile and check the each kernels that how much it take time to compile i mean individual complied timing of each kernels. so you can find easy the main point.
secondly try to use atomic function
as far my six sense says you are using compute buffer right?
if yes try

public GraphicsBuffer Position

Because now a days researchers mostly use the due to modern engine like unity 60000..... the advantage of GraphicBuffer is for both rendering geometry and compute.
Lasty, can you tell us that what is presentation of your particles did you use prefabs or making your own particles as like mentioned in this paper "Figure 2." because they are using there own particle presentations.
also as you mentioned implementations that also has billboard and other particles.
both paper and implementations mostly pipeline are same but the result and rendering is not same.
and also can you tell me that how much it take time for spawn as far i see your codebase i want to know the how much total time is take for just spawn the particle also...
Hope this idea may give you more close to your results.

Q: Does the Gemini API expose its internal “context caching” representation, or is it strictly an opaque server-side cache? A:

You are correct. It is not a storage system, it's a cache, so you still need to maintain the authoritative data source and handle the data retrieval aspects.

Q: Can I remove iPad support from the app store and allow for iPhone only on new version? A:

@hangarrash It would be closed as off topic as a regular question. [So] doesn't handle customer service questions like this.

Q: Google Sheets QUERY using sql to compare two date columns across sheets A:

In your QUERY formula, instead of G = '" & A2 &"' use G = date '" & TEXT(A2, "yyyy-MM-dd") & "'.

Reference

  • https://developers.google.com/chart/interactive/docs/querylanguage

Q: Exponent-Characters shown in string A:

In Python 3, a string is a sequence of Unicode code points, i.e. integers in the range U+0000–U+10FFFF.

Unicode provides superscript characters for individual digits: ⁰ ¹ ² ³ ⁴ ⁵ ⁶ ⁷ ⁸ ⁹.
Those can be used directly or via Unicode escape notation (e.g. \u00b2) in Python strings and will display correctly in terminals and editors that support Unicode.

superscripts = {
    '0': '\u2070', '1': '\u00b9', '2': '\u00b2', '3': '\u00b3', '4': '\u2074',
    '5': '\u2075', '6': '\u2076', '7': '\u2077', '8': '\u2078', '9': '\u2079'
}

If you want to display a multi-digit exponent like “x²³”, Unicode does not provide a single combined superscript representation. You can approximate it by concatenating individual superscript digits (as shown in another answer), but when displayed in a terminal the digits may appear unevenly spaced as in x²³, depending on the font.

If you are working in Jupyter Notebook, you can render multi-digit exponents and LaTeX expressions in general like this instead:


from IPython.display import Math
Math(r"x^{23}")

Q: How to list all available package versions with pip? A:

if you want to install a package named pkg, but don't which versions are available, just try:

pip install pkg==0.0

This will list all available versions that match your python and system OS.

Note: if you see a version release on https://pypi.org but you can list it in command line, check your python version and system OS version.
